Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was on my lunch break, phone pressed to my ear, listening to Mia’s shaky voice. She’d just gotten some harsh feedback from her boss, and I could hear the tears she was trying to hold back. My chest tightened—I wanted nothing more than to comfort her, to tell her she was brilliant and that her boss didn’t see her worth. I glanced at the clock, knowing I had only a few minutes before I had to get back to the site. Suddenly, the shrill site alarm blared, echoing across the yard. My foreman’s voice cut through the noise, shouting for everyone to evacuate. I knew the rules: drop everything, no exceptions, safety first. But Mia’s voice trembled in my ear, “Can you just stay with me for a minute?” My heart pounded as I looked at the streaming crowd of workers heading to the muster point. I was torn—my team needed me to follow protocol, but Mia needed me, too. I stood frozen, phone in hand, caught between the urgent demands of the site and the desperate need in my girlfriend’s voice.
